article:
'Product'(s) are formed during chemical reactions as reagents are consumed.
Products have lower energy than the reagents and are produced during the
reaction according to the second law of thermodynamics. The released energy
comes from changes in chemical bonds between atoms in reagent molecules and may
be given off in the form of heat or light. Products are formed as the chemical
reaction progresses toward chemical equilibrium at a certain reaction rate,
which depends on the reagents and environmental conditions.

Depending on the relative amounts of the reagents and the equilibrium of the
reaction, the terms "reagent" and "product" may also overlap.

But in the end, the product is the result of a chemical reaction.
